properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Risk of freezing rain late tonight followed by rain and snow Saturday. Precipitation will move into the area late tonight. With temperatures near the freezing mark, some of this precipitation may fall as rain or freezing rain. The freezing rain may then last for several hours before a transition to a brief period of heavy snow Saturday afternoon. Current forecast guidance indicates that snowfall accumulations will generally remain low due to relatively mild temperatures, with perhaps 5 cm possible by Saturday evening. However, if temperatures cool more quickly Saturday afternoon, higher snowfall amounts will be possible. Freezing rain warnings may be required as details become more clear. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-25T03:27:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-24T11:28:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3314226133.2020
Area: Kingston - Odessa - Frontenac Islands, Napanee - Consecon, Picton - Sandbanks Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory For The Village Of Pleasantdale
properties.Summary:
Description: A Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory has been issued for Village of Pleasantdale. This advisory is for the Village of Pleasantdale and for any individuals who may access water the Pleasantdale water system. This advisory is in effect until further notice.
Expires: 2020-01-30T17:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Pleasantdale, 2020-01-23T10:23:24-06:00, 8D503EC6-4E09-AFCC-60CC-F531686D6E6A
Area: Village of Pleasantdale
properties.Author: SK Pleasantdale

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A mixed bag of precipitation from Saturday evening through Sunday. A low pressure system from the American Midwest will affect Southwestern Quebec beginning Saturday evening. Precipitation will then gradually spread toward Eastern Quebec. Although precipitation is expected to begin as snow, it is highly possible that it changes to freezing rain over areas near the St Lawrence River and even rain over areas further south. Total snowfall amounts will vary depending on how the system evolves, but they could exceed 15 centimetres over areas north of the St Lawrence River. Additionally, expected rainfall amounts should reach between 10 and 15 millimetres, at this time. Travel could be difficult. At this time, computer model guidance still shows significant variability regarding the system's track. Consequently, there is much uncertainty and the scenario could still change significantly. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-25T02:20:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-24T10:21:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3770262987.2020

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme cold wind chills of -50 and colder developed at Iqaluit today. The cold will persist through tonight and into Friday before moderating somewhat. However, there is potential for the extreme cold to return Friday night and Saturday night. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-24T19:05:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-24T03:06:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1807034103.2020
Area: Iqaluit
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions will continue until Saturday morning with wind gusts up to 100 km/h and periods of snow. Visibilities will be poor in snow and blowing snow during this time period. Blizzard conditions will end Saturday morning as the winds diminish. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-24T23:33:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-24T07:34:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1193702474.2020
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain possible tonight. Rain will move over the highway 7 corridor late this afternoon and spread northward towards Georgian Bay during the evening hours. Over higher elevations, primarily north of a line from Mitchell to St. Jacobs to Guelph, this rain may change to a period of freezing rain this evening. The precipitation is then likely to change to snow tonight or early Saturday morning. It is possible that freezing rain may persist into Saturday morning over the highest elevations of the Dundalk Highlands where ice accretion up to 5 mm could occur. Freezing rain warnings may be required as details become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-25T02:00:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-24T10:01:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2044502331.2020

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentrations of pollutants are expected to persist until late this morning. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-01-25T04:26:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2020-01-24T10:15:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2098973352.2020
Area: Louiseville area, Matawin - Mauricie National Park area, Lac-aux-Sables area, Shawinigan area, Sainte-Anne-de-la-Pérade area, Trois-Rivières area

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 25 cm is expected. A frontal system will bring heavy snow to Kootenay Pass and Paulson Summit tonight. Warm air moving into the interior will cause snow levels to rise tonight, and snow will change to rain at lower elevations. However, near Kootenay Pass and Paulson Summit, snow is expected to continue with snowfall amounts of 20 to 25 cm expected by Friday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-24T14:43:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-23T22:44:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0449592521.2020
Area: Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme cold wind chills of near -55 will develop at Hall Beach and Igloolik this morning. The extreme wind chills will moderate slightly this afternoon. However, extreme cold is expected to return again Friday night and potentially into Saturday as well. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is occurring. An area of fog has moved into the region. The southerly, moist flow will maintain the fog well into the morning. Some improvement may occur midday, but fog is expected to redevelop this evening and persist into Saturday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in blowing snow today through Saturday. A weather system will continue to give snow to the northern Yukon into this weekend. Strong northeasterly winds will continue today. These strong winds will lead to significantly reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Conditions are not expected to improve until at least Saturday. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-25T02:14:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-24T10:15:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0443735994.2020
Area: Old Crow
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills continues. The coldest wind chill values will be near minus 55. Extreme cold conditions will end this afternoon in Gjoa Haven and Taloyoak as temperatures moderate. Wind chill values will moderate slightly in Kugaaruk today, however, extreme cold conditions are expected to return once again tonight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-25T01:30:46-00:00

properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring.
